attributes.mlflow.spanInputs: {"query": "How to check if an endpoint is KMS encrypted?", "context": [{"id": null, "metadata": {"source": "./data/sagemaker_documentation/aws-resource-sagemaker-endpointconfig.md", "_id": "fabb778c-b6bd-4d39-bfd0-9d6b99be7472", "_collection_name": "sagemaker_documentation_v2"}, "page_content": "KmsKeyId The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of an AWS Key Management Service key that Amazon SageMaker uses to encrypt data on the storage volume attached to the ML compute instance that hosts the endpoint. + Key ID: 1234abcd-12ab-34cd-56ef-1234567890ab + Key ARN: arn:aws:kms:us-west-2:111122223333:key/1234abcd-12ab-34cd-56ef-1234567890ab + Alias name: alias/ExampleAlias + Alias name ARN: arn:aws:kms:us-west-2:111122223333:alias/ExampleAlias The KMS key policy must grant permission to the IAM role that you specify in your CreateEndpoint, UpdateEndpoint requests. For more information, refer to the AWS Key Management Service section Using Key Policies in AWS KMS Certain Nitro-based instances include local storage, dependent on the instance type. Local storage volumes are encrypted using a hardware module on the instance. You can't request a KmsKeyId when using an instance type with local", "type": "Document"}, {"id": null, "metadata": {"source": "./data/sagemaker_documentation/aws-properties-sagemaker-endpointconfig-datacaptureconfig.md", "_id": "4a7605f8-efdc-4916-a99a-18a2be2256d9", "_collection_name": "sagemaker_documentation_v2"}, "page_content": "KmsKeyId The AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) key that Amazon SageMaker uses to encrypt the captured data at rest using Amazon S3 server-side encryption. The KmsKeyId can be any of the following formats: Key ID: 1234abcd-12ab-34cd-56ef-1234567890ab Key ARN: arn:aws:kms:us-west-2:111122223333:key/1234abcd-12ab-34cd-56ef-1234567890ab Alias name: alias/ExampleAlias Alias name ARN: arn:aws:kms:us-west-2:111122223333:alias/ExampleAlias If you don't provide a KMS key ID, Amazon SageMaker uses the default KMS key for Amazon S3 for your role's account. For more information, see KMS-Managed Encryption Keys (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/UsingKMSEncryption.html) in the Amazon Simple Storage Service Developer Guide. The KMS key policy must grant permission to the IAM role that you specify in your CreateModel", "type": "Document"}, {"id": null, "metadata": {"source": "./data/sagemaker_documentation/aws-resource-sagemaker-endpointconfig.md", "_id": "5cf80f30-d72d-4aaf-b2a5-efd3de022778", "_collection_name": "sagemaker_documentation_v2"}, "page_content": "Local storage volumes are encrypted using a hardware module on the instance. You can't request a KmsKeyId when using an instance type with local storage. If any of the models that you specify in the ProductionVariants parameter use nitro-based instances with local storage, do not specify a value for the KmsKeyId parameter. If you specify a value for KmsKeyId when using any nitro-based instances with local storage, the call to CreateEndpointConfig fails. For a list of instance types that support local instance storage, see Instance Store Volumes. For more information about local instance storage encryption, see SSD Instance Store Volumes. Required: No Type: String Maximum: 2048 Pattern: .* Update requires: Replacement", "type": "Document"}, {"id": null, "metadata": {"source": "./data/sagemaker_documentation/aws-properties-sagemaker-modelpackage-transformoutput.md", "_id": "73c3e027-2392-4543-91af-52b343b54d10", "_collection_name": "sagemaker_documentation_v2"}, "page_content": "KmsKeyId The AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) key that Amazon SageMaker uses to encrypt the model artifacts at rest using Amazon S3 server-side encryption. The KmsKeyId can be any of the following formats: + Key ID: 1234abcd-12ab-34cd-56ef-1234567890ab + Key ARN: arn:aws:kms:us-west-2:111122223333:key/1234abcd-12ab-34cd-56ef-1234567890ab + Alias name: alias/ExampleAlias + Alias name ARN: arn:aws:kms:us-west-2:111122223333:alias/ExampleAlias If you don't provide a KMS key ID, Amazon SageMaker uses the default KMS key for Amazon S3 for your role's account. For more information, see KMS-Managed Encryption Keys in the Amazon Simple Storage Service Developer Guide. The KMS key policy must grant permission to the IAM role that you specify in your CreateModel request. For more information, see Using Key Policies in AWS KMS in the * AWS Key Management Service Developer Guide. Required: No", "type": "Document"}]}
attributes.mlflow.spanOutputs:
{"result": "To check if an endpoint is KMS encrypted in Amazon SageMaker, you can follow these steps:

1. Open the Amazon SageMaker console in the AWS Management Console.
2. In the navigation pane, choose "Endpoints".
3. Select the endpoint that you want to check.
4. In the details section of the selected endpoint, look for the "Data encryption at rest" field.

If the value of the "Data encryption at rest" field is "KMS", it means that the endpoint is encrypted using KMS. If the value is "SSE-S3", it means that the endpoint is using server-side encryption with Amazon S3-managed keys (SSE-S3) and not KMS encrypted.

Additionally, you can also check the endpoint's configuration to see if it specifies a KMS key ID. If it does, it means that the endpoint is encrypted using KMS. If it does not, it means that the endpoint is using the default KMS key for Amazon S3 for your role's account or SSE-S3.

You can find the endpoint's configuration by:

1. Open the Amazon SageMaker console in the AWS Management Console.
2. In the navigation pane, choose "Endpoints".
3. Select the endpoint that you want to check.
4. In the details section of the selected endpoint, choose the "Endpoint configuration" link.
5. In the endpoint configuration, look for the "KmsKeyId" field.

If the "KmsKeyId" field has a value, it means that the endpoint is encrypted using KMS. If the "KmsKeyId" field is not present or has no value, it means that the endpoint is not encrypted using KMS."}

attributes.mlflow.spanOutputs:
{"output_text": "To check if an endpoint is KMS encrypted in Amazon SageMaker, you can follow these steps:

1. Open the Amazon SageMaker console in the AWS Management Console.
2. In the navigation pane, choose "Endpoints".
3. Select the endpoint that you want to check.
4. In the details section of the selected endpoint, look for the "Data encryption at rest" field.

If the value of the "Data encryption at rest" field is "KMS", it means that the endpoint is encrypted using KMS. If the value is "SSE-S3", it means that the endpoint is using server-side encryption with Amazon S3-managed keys (SSE-S3) and not KMS encrypted.

Additionally, you can also check the endpoint's configuration to see if it specifies a KMS key ID. If it does, it means that the endpoint is encrypted using KMS. If it does not, it means that the endpoint is using the default KMS key for Amazon S3 for your role's account or SSE-S3.

You can find the endpoint's configuration by:

1. Open the Amazon SageMaker console in the AWS Management Console.
2. In the navigation pane, choose "Endpoints".
3. Select the endpoint that you want to check.
4. In the details section of the selected endpoint, choose the "Endpoint configuration" link.
5. In the endpoint configuration, look for the "KmsKeyId" field.

If the "KmsKeyId" field has a value, it means that the endpoint is encrypted using KMS. If the "KmsKeyId" field is not present or has no value, it means that the endpoint is not encrypted using KMS."}

attributes.mlflow.spanInputs:
{"question": "How to check if an endpoint is KMS encrypted?", "context": "KmsKeyId The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of an AWS Key Management Service key that Amazon SageMaker uses to encrypt data on the storage volume attached to the ML compute instance that hosts the endpoint. + Key ID: 1234abcd-12ab-34cd-56ef-1234567890ab + Key ARN: arn:aws:kms:us-west-2:111122223333:key/1234abcd-12ab-34cd-56ef-1234567890ab + Alias name: alias/ExampleAlias + Alias name ARN: arn:aws:kms:us-west-2:111122223333:alias/ExampleAlias The KMS key policy must grant permission to the IAM role that you specify in your CreateEndpoint, UpdateEndpoint requests. For more information, refer to the AWS Key Management Service section Using Key Policies in AWS KMS Certain Nitro-based instances include local storage, dependent on the instance type. Local storage volumes are encrypted using a hardware module on the instance. You can't request a KmsKeyId when using an instance type with local

KmsKeyId The AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) key that Amazon SageMaker uses to encrypt the captured data at rest using Amazon S3 server-side encryption. The KmsKeyId can be any of the following formats: Key ID: 1234abcd-12ab-34cd-56ef-1234567890ab Key ARN: arn:aws:kms:us-west-2:111122223333:key/1234abcd-12ab-34cd-56ef-1234567890ab Alias name: alias/ExampleAlias Alias name ARN: arn:aws:kms:us-west-2:111122223333:alias/ExampleAlias If you don't provide a KMS key ID, Amazon SageMaker uses the default KMS key for Amazon S3 for your role's account. For more information, see KMS-Managed Encryption Keys (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/UsingKMSEncryption.html) in the Amazon Simple Storage Service Developer Guide. The KMS key policy must grant permission to the IAM role that you specify in your CreateModel

Local storage volumes are encrypted using a hardware module on the instance. You can't request a KmsKeyId when using an instance type with local storage. If any of the models that you specify in the ProductionVariants parameter use nitro-based instances with local storage, do not specify a value for the KmsKeyId parameter. If you specify a value for KmsKeyId when using any nitro-based instances with local storage, the call to CreateEndpointConfig fails. For a list of instance types that support local instance storage, see Instance Store Volumes. For more information about local instance storage encryption, see SSD Instance Store Volumes. Required: No Type: String Maximum: 2048 Pattern: .* Update requires: Replacement

KmsKeyId The AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) key that Amazon SageMaker uses to encrypt the model artifacts at rest using Amazon S3 server-side encryption. The KmsKeyId can be any of the following formats: + Key ID: 1234abcd-12ab-34cd-56ef-1234567890ab + Key ARN: arn:aws:kms:us-west-2:111122223333:key/1234abcd-12ab-34cd-56ef-1234567890ab + Alias name: alias/ExampleAlias + Alias name ARN: arn:aws:kms:us-west-2:111122223333:alias/ExampleAlias If you don't provide a KMS key ID, Amazon SageMaker uses the default KMS key for Amazon S3 for your role's account. For more information, see KMS-Managed Encryption Keys in the Amazon Simple Storage Service Developer Guide. The KMS key policy must grant permission to the IAM role that you specify in your CreateModel request. For more information, see Using Key Policies in AWS KMS in the * AWS Key Management Service Developer Guide. Required: No"}

3. Select the endpoint that you want to check.
4. In the details section of the selected endpoint, look for the "Data encryption at rest" field.

If the value of the "Data encryption at rest" field is "KMS", it means that the endpoint is encrypted using KMS. If the value is "SSE-S3", it means that the endpoint is using server-side encryption with Amazon S3-managed keys (SSE-S3) and not KMS encrypted.

Additionally, you can also check the endpoint's configuration to see if it specifies a KMS key ID. If it does, it means that the endpoint is encrypted using KMS. If it does not, it means that the endpoint is using the default KMS key for Amazon S3 for your role's account or SSE-S3.

You can find the endpoint's configuration by:

1. Open the Amazon SageMaker console in the AWS Management Console.
2. In the navigation pane, choose "Endpoints".
3. Select the endpoint that you want to check.
4. In the details section of the selected endpoint, choose the "Endpoint configuration" link.
5. In the endpoint configuration, look for the "KmsKeyId" field.

If the "KmsKeyId" field has a value, it means that the endpoint is encrypted using KMS. If the "KmsKeyId" field is not present or has no value, it means that the endpoint is not encrypted using KMS."}

The KmsKeyId can be any of the following formats: + Key ID: 1234abcd-12ab-34cd-56ef-1234567890ab + Key ARN: arn:aws:kms:us-west-2:111122223333:key/1234abcd-12ab-34cd-56ef-1234567890ab + Alias name: alias/ExampleAlias + Alias name ARN: arn:aws:kms:us-west-2:111122223333:alias/ExampleAlias If you don't provide a KMS key ID, Amazon SageMaker uses the default KMS key for Amazon S3 for your role's account. For more information, see KMS-Managed Encryption Keys in the Amazon Simple Storage Service Developer Guide. The KMS key policy must grant permission to the IAM role that you specify in your CreateModel request. response:
{"result": "To check if an endpoint is KMS encrypted in Amazon SageMaker, you can follow these steps:

1. Open the Amazon SageMaker console in the AWS Management Console.
2. In the navigation pane, choose "Endpoints".
3. Select the endpoint that you want to check.
4. In the details section of the selected endpoint, look for the "Data encryption at rest" field.

If the value of the "Data encryption at rest" field is "KMS", it means that the endpoint is encrypted using KMS. If the value is "SSE-S3", it means that the endpoint is using server-side encryption with Amazon S3-managed keys (SSE-S3) and not KMS encrypted.

Additionally, you can also check the endpoint's configuration to see if it specifies a KMS key ID. If it does, it means that the endpoint is encrypted using KMS. If it does not, it means that the endpoint is using the default KMS key for Amazon S3 for your role's account or SSE-S3.

You can find the endpoint's configuration by:

1. Open the Amazon SageMaker console in the AWS Management Console.
2. In the navigation pane, choose "Endpoints".
3. Select the endpoint that you want to check.
4. In the details section of the selected endpoint, choose the "Endpoint configuration" link.
5. In the endpoint configuration, look for the "KmsKeyId" field.

If the "KmsKeyId" field has a value, it means that the endpoint is encrypted using KMS. If the "KmsKeyId" field is not present or has no value, it means that the endpoint is not encrypted using KMS."}
